Dear Ms. Klinski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
A third provisional license is recommended. If you do not contest the issuance of a
provisional license, you must indicate so in writing. If you contest the issuance of a
provisional license, you must notify this office in writing and an administrative hearing will
be scheduled. Please submit form CWL-4617 to indicate your intentions. Even if you
contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must still submit an acceptable
corrective action plan.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Rorie Dodge, Licensing Consultant

ALLEGATION:
Facility is not always in ratio and sometimes one staff is monitoring two pods.
Sometimes there are no staff to supervise, youth are left without supervision, and
rooms are left unlocked.
INVESTIGATION:
A complaint was received on 6/8/21. The complaint alleged that the facility is not
always in ratio. Some staff have been left alone to watch two pods at once. The last
time this occurred was on 6/6/21. Staff and youth have confirmed that they are not
always in ratio. Youth reported sometimes they do not have a staff to supervise
them, and they are told to “self-regulate.” During this time their doors are left
unlocked, and they are to supervise themselves.
At the facility on 6/10/21 the Program Director (PD) was informed of the allegations.
He also provided the schedules for the last two weeks. The schedule indicated that
one staff was scheduled on each pod for all AM and PM shifts. Staff 5 was listed as
working the PM shift on 6/6/21. The PD reported Pod A had five youth and Pod B
had seven youth on 6/5/21 and 6/6/21.
Youth A was interviewed at the facility on 6/10/21. He resides on Pod B. Prior to this
day the Pod had 7 youth and now there are 6. They staff one staff on each Pod and
sometimes one person watches two pods. Staff 5 has been left to watch two Pods
by herself. She stays in the control room so she can see both pods.
Youth B was interviewed at the facility on 6/10/21. He reported the facility is not any
different than a hold facility (detention center). The facility does not do any
treatment. He is on Pod B with 5 other youth, the previous day it was 6 other youth.
There is 1 staff on each Pod and sometimes 1 staff on 2 Pods. A few days ago,
Staff 5 was left alone to watch 2 Pods.
Youth C was interviewed at the facility on 6/10/21. He is on Pod B. The facility is
short on staff. His group has been left on their pod alone with no staff. When they
are short on staff in the "State" (DHHS Contracted) pods then the staff move over to
one of those pods. This has happened for an entire morning until they are to step
down for shift change at 1:20pm. When they were left alone on their pod there would
be a staff on Pod A. When this happens the boys on Pod B are let out of their rooms.
Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility on 6/10/21. He stated he is a shift supervisor
on midnights. He was currently working the AM shift because he was mandated to
stay over. He said this happens because they are short staffed. He is used to having
to stay over and does not mind it. The youth cannot be outside their rooms without
staff supervision. The staff walk by the bedrooms and do 15-minute checks while the
youth are in their bedrooms. The youth are always supposed to be supervised.
When he works the AM he works on the pod by himself. They had 7 youth on the
3

pod but one of them left earlier in the morning so now they have 6. On Saturdays in
the morning the group has level expectation group, Sunday they do goal sheets and
social living skills. They go to the gym on Saturday and Sunday morning. The TV
can be on and Pod B is allowed to watch TV. He has not heard of the boys being on
the pod alone. One staff has been responsible for 2 pods before, but it does not
happen very often.
Youth D was interviewed on 6/10/21. He is currently on Pod B. The facility is low on
staff. There have been times when one staff will be responsible for 2 pods. The
youth on Pod B take care of themselves.
Youth E was interviewed at the facility on 6/10/21. He is on Pod B. They sometimes
do not have staff for their pod. There will be one staff for both pods. This happened
3-4 days ago with Staff 5. During that time, they have to sit by their door. Staff 5 sits
in the middle of the control room in order to watch both pods. The staff are not able
to keep a good eye on them this way and stuff happens like youth walking around
without permission. None of the rules are followed during that time.
Youth F was interviewed at the facility on 6/10/21. Youth F resides on Pod B. Three
days ago, there was no staff on their pod. They ran the pod by themselves. One staff
was watching both pods from the control room. His group is mature, so they do what
they need to do.
Staff 2 was interviewed at the facility on 6/17/21. He is a supervisor and has been
working at the facility for 4 years. He works morning shift five days a week. Today he
is working on Pod B. He reported they usually have enough staff to staff all the pods.
Pod A has a state contract and Pod B does not. If they have six youth on Pod A
there has to be 2 staff but that is not the case on Pod B. Pod B only needs one staff.
He said the only time there is one staff for two pods is when someone is running
late. During COVID their staff numbers decreased. He believes they are coming out
of it, but still have a ways to go. Due to the staffing shortage treatment has been
lacking and they have to get it back to where it was. The kids respect consistent staff
that they have built rapport with making it easier to provide treatment. When they
have new staff all the time it is hard to do that. He reported at 1:45pm the youth go
to their rooms for reflection time for 30 minutes. They do another head count at
2:15pm then it is the end of the shift. He only works morning shift so he could not
speak of what occurs on PM shift.
Staff 3 was interviewed at the facility on 6/17/21. He was upset and stated he has
been working too much. He is seldom on Pod B. He did not remember the last time
he worked on Pod B. He reported only 1 staff is needed for each Pod. He has
worked two pods with just himself before. He stated he and his co-workers have
been expressing their concerns about staffing every day.
Case Files: All case files were reviewed for all six youth residing on Pod B. The last
Treatment Plan completed for each one of them was reviewed. The Treatment
4

Plan’s indicate Staff 4 was meeting with the youth individually one time a week, they
were participating in various group therapy and family therapy for those boys who
required it.
Video Review: A video from 6/5/21 starting at 7:45am and ending at 9:28pm was
reviewed. The youth are by themselves in the day room for most of the day. At one
point a staff is seen engaging with the youths, but he is also on his cell phone. The
video for 6/6/21 is the same as 6/5. It starts at 6:26am and ends at 9:27pm. On 6/6
the youth are seen trying to get a staff to come to the pod by waving their arms at
the camera or going to the pod door.
On 6/17/21 a visit was made to Pod B. Staff were present on the Pod.
Staff 4 Interview: Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on 6/28/21. She stated she
is the clinical case manager for Pod B, and she has worked at the facility for 13
years. The facility has been out of ratio for a while and sometimes only one person is
responsible to watch Pod A and Pod B. When asked she confirmed that some of the
acting out from the youth was due to being short staffed but also due to lack of
experienced staff.
Staff 5 did not return phone call request for an interview.
The facility’s Youth Supervision and Staffing policy states the minimum ratio in
the facility is one staff to every five youth on the DHHS contracted pods and one
staff to every eight youth on the other pods.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-
to-resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
ANALYSIS: It was reported by both staff and youth that sometimes both Pod
A and Pod B are supervised by one staff member. While the
video does not show who was in the control room a staff
member is rarely seen engaging or supervising the youth from
the dayroom on 6/5 and 6/6. Staff 2 reported Pod A is a
contracted pod and Pod B is not. Pod B had seven youth on
6/5/21 and Pod A had five youth. This is not within the facilities
policy which indicates there must be one staff to every five youth
on the contracted pod and one staff to eight youth on the non-
contracted pod.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2020C0108068, CAP approved on 11/24/20
5

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: Both youth and staff reported the facility does not currently have
enough staff. The youth interviewed indicated they do not get
the programing that they are supposed to get, and staff
interviewed indicated some of the programming is not provided
when the facility is short on staff. The video of 6/5/21 and 6/6/21
demonstrated there was not enough staff to properly supervise
the youth.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2021C0201016, CAP approved 3/18/21
SIR 2019C0219045, CAP approved on 10/9/19
ALLEGATION:
Due to staffing shortages, staff are working double shifts leading to staff sleeping on
duty.
INVESTIGATION:
The above complaint also alleged that staff are being mandated to stay over and
work a second shift due to not having enough staff to work. Due to staff being
mandated to stay after working an overnight shift they are falling asleep while on
duty.
Youth A reported some of the staff sleep when they are working. The day of the
interview Staff 1 was seen sleeping around 12pm. Youth A has seen Staff 1 sleep on
the Pod and in the gym.
Youth B reported he saw Staff 1 sleeping in the classroom. He was in the back
sleeping. The teacher was also there. Staff 3 also sleeps. He has been seen
sleeping in the control room.
Youth C reported that Staff 1 sleeps. Staff 1 works overnights then stays to work the
AM shift and that is when he falls asleep. Today Staff 1 was sleeping in their class,
and he has seen Staff 1 sleeping in the gym.
6

Staff 1 stated he does not get too tired when working the AM shift but sometimes he
gets fatigued. When he gets tired, he will walk around or call for a "28" which is a
break. Recently he has not fallen asleep, but he did about 2-3 months ago. He said
this happened on the midnight shift when he was in the control room by himself.
Youth D stated some of the staff sleep under blind spots. The midnight staff, Staff 1
and Staff 3, sleep. Staff 1 was sleeping in the classroom earlier in the day.
Youth E reported Staff 1 sleeps. Today in the morning on the pod he slept and at
school in the classroom. On the pod Staff 1 was sitting next to Youth E when he fell
asleep.
Youth F stated sometimes staff get tired from being mandated to stay over. Then
they end up falling asleep. He has seen Staff 1 and Staff 3 sleeping. Today Staff 1
was sleeping in the classroom.
Staff 2 reported the staff work a lot of hours. If he notices a staff that is tired, he will
address the staff and have them take a break.
Staff 3 works nights and is mandated every day to stay for the AM shift. On this day
he worked the overnight then stayed for the AM shift. He admitted he has fallen
asleep during work. When he has to work 16 hours a day, he gets tired and nods off.
Video Review: A video of the classroom from 6/10/21 was viewed. Staff 1 was
sitting against the wall. Several times it appears that Staff 1 doses off as his head is
down. The teacher enters the room and Staff 1 sits up. He appears to stay awake
while the teacher is in the room.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
7

ANALYSIS: The staff interviewed reported they are often mandated to stay
over from their night shift because there are not enough staff to
cover the AM shift. Working eight hours after having to stay up
all night makes the staff tired during the AM shift and they doze
off. Staff being mandated to cover unfilled shifts indicates the
facility does not have a sufficient number of staff to provide for
the supervision of the youth.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2021C0201016, CAP approved 3/18/21
SIR 2019C0219045, CAP approved on 10/9/19
ALLEGATION:
Youth are disciplined as a group at times and not receiving their privileges.
INVESTIGATION:
It was further alleged that the group is being disciplined when any of the youth act
up. Staff 4 implements “cease movement” for the entire group in which they are not
allowed to watch TV, listen to the radio, play games, or have recreation time. They
are also not allowed to utilize the tables on the pod. The youth are to sit in chairs at
their doors.
Youth A reported when the group is put on “cease movement” they all have to sit by
their doors and are not allowed to do anything. After school they do not do anything
until dinner. They are not allowed to play games or watch TV. They can go to their
rooms. They are also required to eat in their chair. Youth A said the group was put
on cease movement about a month ago and they are still on it. They were put on
cease movement when the entire pod was doing bad. They are supposed to do
groups, but the therapist does not do them. The therapist will sometimes meet with
them individually.
Youth B reported cease movement is when they cannot do anything. They are not
allowed to move around the building except to go to school. They are supposed to
have game time during school, but they are not allowed to do that on cease
movement. The youth sit and do nothing all day, then at shower time they go into
their rooms. He believes the staff are afraid of the therapist. The therapist told them
that the "state" (DCWL) does not work the pod therefore they did not have to do
what the state says. The therapist took their TV remote home so they could not
watch TV.
Youth C reported their handbook states they are to have family sessions and
individual or group therapy, but they do not get it while on cease movement. They do
not do groups or any treatment. Their therapist does not talk to them and does not
have family sessions. The therapist took their TV remote home so they could not
8

watch TV. They have to sit on the floor in the pod to eat dinner. The youth just sit at
their doors and talk all day. They are not allowed to use the multipurpose room or go
to the classroom.
Youth D reported Pod B is currently on cease movement which means they have to
sit by their doors. He stated they were put on cease movement because one of his
peers had food in his room. He is supposed to get family sessions but doesn't. There
are no therapy groups. The therapist is in control of everything, and she took away
their TV and radio. The other staff and supervisors are afraid to confront her, so they
let her have too much control. The pod is not allowed to participate in gym unless it
is for school.
Staff 1 indicated cease movement means the youth are not to move about the
building due to a safety issue. The managers call it when there is a safety issue. It
lasts until the safety issue has been resolved. He gave an example of a youth
needing to be taken by ambulance and the EMT's needing to go to the pod to get
him. The youth were not on cease movement today. When the youth are behaving
poorly, they can be on cease movement which indicates they cannot move about the
building, but they can move around the pod.
Youth E reported the youth on his pod are not allowed to watch TV and the therapist
took their remote. They were told this was due to bad behavior however there has
not been any write-ups or other consequences. She also took their gym time away.
They sit on the pod by their bedroom doors. They have to eat on the pod. They eat
siting on the floor and use their chair as a table because the therapist took their
tables away. The therapist calls this cease movement. They do not receive any
treatment or treatment groups. They circle up with the therapist once every 2 weeks
when she wants to move one of them up a level. They do not receive individual
therapy. They are supposed to get it every week. The therapist does not talk to them
when they are on cease movement, but she did talk to Youth E when he had court.
They eat every meal on the pod, and they are not allowed to use the tables due to
cease movement. He did not know why they were put on cease movement as there
has not been any consequences earned by any of them.
Youth F stated his group was put on cease movement for no reason. Their games
and TV were taken away. They go to school, but they are not allowed to go to the
gym or to the game room. They have to just sit by their doors when on the pod. He
sometimes meets with his therapist, but it is supposed to be weekly. He probably
meets with her once a month. She does not do any groups.
Staff 2 reported cease movement means the youth cannot leave the Pod. This is
done due to behavioral issues. Usually, the entire Pod is put on cease movement
not just one person, but it can be done for just one person. He said it depends on the
behaviors. The youth are allowed to watch TV and play games depending on their
behaviors. The youth go outside on certain days. The therapist decides when they
can go outside. They can also go to the gym. A normal day starts with head count at
9

6:15am. The youth can come out of their rooms after that. They then do their detail
(clean their room). At 7:30am they do affirmations which is a group in which they talk
about their feelings and goals for the day. Breakfast is at 8am. The group eats on
the Pod due to COVID. The youth have tables they use when they eat. Then they go
to school. They are in the same classroom for all of their core subjects then different
rooms for Art and Gym. 11:30 am is lunch on the Pod. 12:30 they are back in class.
Staff 4 reported the youth do get therapy on cease movement. She provides
individual, family, and group therapy. The youth receive individual therapy one time
a week, group therapy five days a week, and family therapy once a month. The only
time the youth did not get their therapy was when they were on quarantine which
was about a month ago. One of the youths on the Pod had COVID so the youth
were not allowed to leave their rooms. There have also been times when the youth
were acting out and they could not meet. She reported she was not comfortable
meeting with the youth alone when they were acting out and there was not enough
staff to support her. The group was put on cease movement because there was a lot
of fighting. Two youth “jumped” another youth. Other kids also tried to fight youth
from Pod A. Some youth would not go to their rooms and drew with a marker on the
windows and tables. Youth broke the TV and took a fire extinguisher to a bedroom.
There was a lot of stuff going on and they were short on staff. The youth were
arguing a lot. Staff 4 said this has been going on since before COVID. The older
youth have a "street mentality." She reported there was not enough security to
break up the fights so the only thing she could do was have them in their rooms.
Case Files: All case files were reviewed for all six-youth residing on Pod B. The last
Treatment Plan completed for each one of them was reviewed. The Treatment
Plan’s indicate Staff 4 was meeting with the youth individually one time a week, they
were participating in various group therapy and family therapy for those youths who
required it.
Therapy notes: Therapy notes for the six youth on Pod B were reviewed. The notes
indicated from 4/30 to 6/9/21 the youth were meeting with the therapist or were
observed by the therapist except for two of those seven weeks the youth were not
met with as they were on quarantine due to suspected COVID. The notes indicate
the youth were receiving case management and not therapy. The therapist would go
over their level work and their behavior. The notes indicate the group was on "cease
movement" from 5/12/21 until after 6/11/21 for group members having contraband in
their rooms, getting into a physical altercation, and not following the rules. Family
sessions were phone calls to the family member and did not include the youth.
Youth were reprimanded for talking to each other and playing cards while on cease
movement. All therapy notes indicate the youth were participating in therapy groups
even when they were quarantined.
The facility did not have any documentation to indicate what cease movement is and
when it is to be used.
10

The Student Handbook indicates the following:
Level system bedtimes:
Level 1 bedtime 8pm
Level 2 and 3 8:30pm
Level 4 9pm
Level 5 9:30pm
Consequences listed are apologizing, doing worksheets, loss of privileges, loss of
level, restitution, thinking table, and alternate programing. The handbook does not
indicate anything about cease movement.
Alternate programing is for youth who continually exhibit a disregard for the code of
conduct and safety. It is a modification of an individual’s treatment plan and program
path for a specific resident. The thinking table is removing a youth from the group
and supervised separately. The youth can only talk to staff, they can only have a
work assignment to do at the table. They can do recreation with the group but
cannot interact and they have to eat their meals separate from the group.
The Handbook also states the youth are to receive regular physical and recreational
activities, family therapy, and group work.
The CA reported youth on Pod B were all on level one with the exception of Youth A
who was on level 3. This level system is a merit system based on 5 levels with 5
being the highest and 1 being the lowest.
The Residential Services Policy states the facility will provide all essential
elements to the physical and emotional well-being of the youth. The daily routines
are to keep youth constructively engaged and support the youths emotional and
behavioral stability. The schedule listed that groups would be provided daily even on
Saturday and Sunday.
The Video reviewed of 6/5/21 and 6/6/21 indicate all youth went to bed at the same
time. Despite Youth A being on level 3. It also showed that the youth did not do
groups or engage in activities with the exception of gym.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.158 Discipline.
(2) An institution shall prohibit all cruel and severe discipline,
including any of the following:
(b) Disciplining a group for the misbehavior of individual
group members.
(d) Denial of any essential program services, including
adoption planning.
ANALYSIS: Interviews with the youth and therapy notes indicated the youth on
11

Pod B were all on cease movement. There is no indication that all
the youth were engaging in the negative behaviors.
The youth all indicated due to being on cease movement they were
not provided with individual, group, or family therapy. The therapist
notes indicate individual therapy was minimal and there was no
family therapy. Video of 6/5/21 and 6/6/21 indicate the youth did not
receive group as indicated on the schedule and bedtimes were all
the same even though one youth was on level 3.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2021C0201024, CAP approved 4/15/21
SIR 2021C0108004, CAP approved 12/23/20
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4157 Behavior management.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies and
procedures that describe the institution’s behavior management
system. The policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually and
updated as needed. These shall be available to all residents, their
families, and referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: The youth and therapist all indicate all the youth were on cease
movement due to negative behavior, however, the student handbook
and the facilities policies and procedures do not list cease
movement as a consequence.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATIONS:
Youth are locked in their rooms for extended periods of time.
INVESTIGATION:
The above complaint alleged that the youth on Pod B were locked in their rooms for an
excessive amount of time.
Youth A stated at 6:30pm the group does showers. The showers take five minutes
each and there are two showers on the pod. The youth have to all be in their rooms
during showers. After taking their showers they have to go back into their rooms for the
night.
Youth B reported the last time the "State" was at the facility they were able to come out
of their rooms on time but when the "State" leaves they come out of their rooms late.
12

They come out of their room at 8am and get to class late. After school they have
reflection time in their rooms. They go back in their rooms during shower times.
Youth C said the staff always let the boys out of their rooms when the state (DCWL) is
visiting the facility otherwise they stay in their room from 1:20pm to 4pm. Then they are
back in their rooms at 6:30pm. One at a time they come out to take their showers.
Youth D reported the group goes to their rooms around 6 or 6:30pm then they come out
the following morning around 8am. They also spend time in their room for reflection
which is from 1:30pm to 4pm. They are supposed to come out at 2:30pm.
Staff 1 stated the youth start school at 8:30am. They get out of school at 1:45pm then
are in their rooms for reflection time. They are in their rooms for 30 minutes during shift
change. He leaves at 2pm so he does not know what the youth do after that. In the
morning they open the bedroom doors at 6am but the youth usually stay sleeping.
Sometimes the doors are opened later due to being short staffed.
Staff 2 reported 1:45pm the youth go to their rooms for reflection time for 30 minutes
then it is the end of the shift. He only works morning shift so he could not speak of what
occurs on PM shift.
The video of 6/5/21 was reviewed. The youth come out of their rooms around 8:30am.
The youth were back in their rooms starting at 1:25pm. They are let out at 3:51pm. At
6:30pm the youth are in their rooms. The youth come out one or two at a time to shower
then they are back in their rooms. One youth linger outside his room the entire time.
Lights are turned out at 7:45pm and all youth are in their rooms with their doors shut.
The video shows staff checking the rooms at 7:50pm, 9:22pm, and 9:28pm. The video
then ends at 9:28pm.
The video of 6/6/21 was reviewed. Staff checked the bedrooms at 6:26am. The rooms
are checked again at 7:03am and 7:35am. The bedroom doors are opened at 8:04am.
At 1:24pm the youth are in their rooms with the doors closed and the lights out. Staff
check the rooms at 2:08pm. The youth are let out of their rooms at 3:20pm. The youth
are back in their rooms at 6:09pm. Two youth at a time exit to shower. All youth are
back in their rooms with the doors closed and the lights out at 7:27pm. Staff are seen on
the video sliding what appears to be a snack under each bedroom door. Staff are not
seen checking the bedrooms until 9:27pm.
Neither video indicate behavior from any of the youth that would warrant seclusion in
their bedrooms.
The Residential Services Policy states the Saturday and Sunday Routine is:
7:15-8:30 is AM routine
1:30-1:50 is an activity
1:50-2:15 reflection (done in their rooms with the doors shut)
2:15-3 Task work/homework
13

3 - 4:30 Group
6:30-9:30 PM Routine
Sleeping hours are not to exceed 10 hours from 8pm to 6am
During a walkthrough of the facility, it was found that the bedroom doors lock when they
are closed.
The Room Monitoring Records were requested for 6/5/21 and 6/6/21. The forms
indicated that on 6/5/21 the staff did room checks from 1:45pm to 3:45pm and from
6:00pm to 6:00am on 6/6. On 6/6 staff did room checks from 1:30pm to 2:45pm and
from 6:30pm – 11:45pm on 6/6. The records indicated that these checks were always
completed on the quarter hour.
The facility’s Use of Seclusion Room’s policy states the only time the youth can be
secluded is if they are in the act of harming themselves, assaulting someone,
committing a serious act of destruction of property that places the youth or others at
risk, jeopardizing the safety of others or jeopardizing the security of himself or others
and if de-escalation techniques were unsuccessful. Seclusion may not be used as a
form of punishment and shall be performed in a way that is safe, appropriate, and
proportionate to the severity of the youth’s behavior.
A previous investigation 2020C0108070 completed in September of 2020 found that
youth were locked in their rooms for an extended period of time. The facility did not
have a policy on Regular Sleeping hours. The report stated that the policy should
indicate what those regular sleeping hours are and “The youth’s doors would remain
unlocked outside of those times unless the youth is secluded per the definition of
seclusion in PA 116. Youth can only be confined in a room if seclusion is justified due
to misconduct, harm to self, others or property.” The corrective action was to create a
policy that indicated the regular sleeping hours would not exceed ten hours from 8pm to
6am.
I reviewed Public Act 116 - MCL 722.112b Definitions; scope of seclusion.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4161 Seclusion rooms; policies and procedures.
An institution approved to use a seclusion room shall establish
and follow written policies and procedures specifying its use.
The policy shall include, at a minimum, all of the following
provisions:
(a) Seclusion shall be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of
the minor child’s behavior, chronological and
developmental age, size, gender, physical condition,
14

medical condition, psychiatric condition, and personal
history, including any history of trauma.
(b) The room may only be used if a resident is in
danger of jeopardizing the safety and security of
himself, herself, or others.
(c) The room shall be used only for the time needed to
change the behavior compelling its use.
(e) Staff shall observe the resident at intervals of 15
minutes or less and shall record the observation in a
seclusion room log. Video surveillance shall not be the
only means of observation.
ANALYSIS: The youth all reported they are in their rooms longer than
necessary. The video of 6/5/21 and 6/6/21 showed youth
locked in their rooms from approximately 1:30 to 3-4pm and
about 7:30pm to 8:30am. The video does not show any of the
youth displaying behavior that would warrant a seclusion.
The video also showed that staff were not conducting 15-
minute varying interval checks while the youth were secluded
in their bedrooms.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
